ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Left temporal-parietal astrocytoma with corpus callosum compromise
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: MRI confirms lesion site; central testing shows right ear deficits (contralateral cortex) and bilateral dichotic deficits (corpus callosum involvement).

ordered_list.rationale_short: Assess monaural low-redundancy processing (sensitive to cortical lesions).
Assess dichotic processing and interhemispheric transfer.
Assess temporal patterning and interhemispheric transfer.
Evaluate late latency responses and cognitive auditory processing.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: Peripheral hearing is essentially normal. Central behavioral testing reveals a distinct pattern consistent with the left temporal-parietal lesion and corpus callosum compromise: Right ear deficits on Low Pass Filtered Speech (contralateral ear effect due to left auditory cortex involvement) and bilateral deficits on dichotic tasks and Frequency Patterns (attributed to both the lesion and compromised interhemispheric transfer). P300 waveforms were noisy but showed bilaterally extended peaks.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.result_summary: Normal thresholds bilaterally (0-15 dB HL) from 250-4000 Hz, with mild high-frequency depression at 8000 Hz (~35-40 dB HL).

tests.name: Low Pass Filtered Speech
tests.result_summary: Abnormal in the Right Ear (~60%); Normal in the Left Ear (~85-90%).

tests.name: Auditory Evoked Potentials (P300)
tests.result_summary: Waveforms were noisy; P300 showed bilaterally extended peaks for both recording sites (C3, C4) and ears.

proposed_items: Monitor auditory function and neurological status longitudinally
counseling_actions: Explain that difficulty hearing in noise or with competing speech is expected due to central processing deficits despite normal peripheral hearing
Discuss 'alien hand syndrome' as consistent with the neurological findings
Highlight that the stability of the auditory findings correlates with the stability of the lesion
Recommend communication strategies to reduce background noise and competing messages

escalation.rationale_short: Continued monitoring of known stable inoperable astrocytoma.

follow_up_plan.objective: Assess stability of auditory function in relation to the neurological condition.

expected_outcome: Patient's condition remains stable with no dramatic changes in lesion size or auditory findings over time.
Patient retains 'alien hand syndrome' and subtle subjective auditory difficulties.
Patient functions well in everyday situations but electively does not drive.
